message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The visual field test shows a central scotoma, which suggests occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. Degeneration of the macula would not cause a central scotoma, impaired perfusion of the retina would cause peripheral visual field defects, and occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery would cause contralateral motor and sensory deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pulse rate and irregularity suggest atrial fibrillation, a common cause of thromboembolic events including occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The visual field testing with a scotoma supports this diagnosis. Degeneration of the macula and impaired perfusion of the retina would show different visual field defects. Occlusion of anterior cerebral artery would result in motor and sensory deficits rather than visual changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The visual field testing shows a loss of vision in the right temporal and left nasal fields, which suggest a homonymous hemianopsia. This is usually caused by an occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery, which supplies the occipital lobe responsible for vision. Impaired perfusion of the retina would cause a loss of vision in a more peripheral field. Macular degeneration would not cause a sudden loss of vision as described. Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery would not involve the occipital lobe and would cause different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of decreased vision and worsening headaches, along with an irregular pulse, suggest a possible embolic event. The findings of visual field testing and the patient's medical history make posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion the most likely cause of her symptoms. Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery would affect the contralateral leg and pelvis, not the visual fields. Impaired perfusion of the retina would not typically cause these symptoms, and degeneration of the macula would not present with a visual field deficit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of decreased vision and worsening headaches, and the visual field testing shows a homonymous hemianopia, which is most commonly caused by occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. None of the other options are consistent with the symptoms or test results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The visual field deficits shown in the visual field testing suggest a posterior cerebral artery occlusion. Macular degeneration would not cause these findings. Impaired perfusion of the retina would cause visual field deficits but not the specific deficits shown in the visual field testing. Anterior cerebral artery occlusion would result in deficits mainly in the lower extremities and not show up in visual field testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a posterior cerebral artery occlusion. The visual field defect on one side and the irregular pulse suggest a cardiovascular cause, and hypertension is a risk factor for stroke. There are no findings suggesting degeneration of the macula or impaired perfusion of the retina. Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery would cause motor and sensory impairment on the opposite side of the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pulse irregularity suggests atrial fibrillation, which can lead to embolism resulting in occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The visual field defects suggest the posterior cerebral artery territory is affected. The other options are less likely based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pulse is irregular, and the visual field testing shows a homonymous hemianopsia, suggesting a stroke. In this case, the most likely cause is occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. Degeneration of the macula does not cause a visual field defect, impaired perfusion of the retina would cause visual loss in one eye, and occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery would cause a different pattern of visual field loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the irregular pulse suggest a cardioembolic source. The visual field defect is congruent with an occipital lobe infarct, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. Degeneration of the macula will cause central visual field loss, while impaired perfusion of the retina will cause decreased peripheral vision. Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery will cause hemiparesis and personality changes.
